title: 105_s2207
content: The "Antitrust Improvements Act of 1998" aims to empower the Attorney General to prevent mergers that could harm competition in the telecommunications industry. It amends the Clayton Act to address restraints of trade in telecommunications. The "Antitrust Improvements Act of 1998" defines a large local telephone company as one serving more than 5 percent of telephone access lines in the US. It prohibits mergers or acquisitions of such companies unless approved by the Attorney General to promote competition in the telecommunications industry. The "Antitrust Improvements Act of 1998" prohibits mergers or acquisitions of large local telephone companies unless approved by the Attorney General and the FCC to promote competition in the telecommunications industry. The "Antitrust Improvements Act of 1998" requires approval from the Attorney General and the FCC for mergers or acquisitions of large local telephone companies to ensure compliance with telecommunications regulations. The Antitrust Improvements Act of 1998 mandates approval from the Attorney General and the FCC for mergers or acquisitions of large local telephone companies to comply with telecommunications regulations. The Attorney General must report findings on the impact of the merger on competition to the Senate and House Judiciary Committees within 10 days. The Attorney General must report findings on the impact of mergers or acquisitions of large local telephone companies to the Senate and House Judiciary Committees, including an analysis of the effect on competition in the telecommunications industry. Large local telephone companies proposing mergers must file an application with both committees. The application process for large local telephone companies proposing mergers or acquisitions involves filing an application with the Attorney General and the Federal Communications Commission simultaneously. The decision on the application must be made within the specified time period. The Attorney General and the Federal Communications Commission must issue a decision on mergers or acquisitions within a specific time frame. The district courts have jurisdiction to prevent any inconsistent mergers or acquisitions. The Attorney General can initiate legal proceedings in any district court. The Attorney General can take legal action in district courts to prevent mergers or acquisitions that do not meet specified conditions. The Attorney General can seek legal action in district courts to stop mergers or acquisitions that fail to meet certain conditions. This includes obtaining injunctive relief if the proposed merger does not meet the conditions specified. SEC. 4 of the Act preserves existing authorities related to antitrust laws and the Federal Communications Commission's powers under the Communications Act of 1934 regarding mergers, acquisitions, and affiliations of large incumbent local exchange carriers. Antitrust laws are defined as per the Clayton Act. The Act and its amendments apply to mergers or acquisitions of controlling interests in large local telephone companies after the enactment date.
